document.title: Washington, DC K-12 Social Studies Standards Revised Standards

38FE645ED263492D819FA1E1243770C8.description:
Evaluate the creation of the United States and the ways it may serve as an example (both for its strengths and limitations)
to other democracies around the world.

F92FC5E4CD0F44D9BF889C2B76182EFD.description: Analyze the reasons for, and impact of, the expansion of rights, including the right to vote, in the United States over time.

E9C93853E12E485780E9C05108CBAF40.description:
Evaluate the credibility or perspective of online sources and claims about the history or application of the United States
Constitution using strategies like lateral reading.

A9FA7BCA2C144875854E6611B1AA2C8E.description: Analyze the political motivations that led to Washington, DC being established as the capital of the United States.

F913D18D32464FA9942D1360C1493162.description:
Explain protections that the Bill of Rights provides to individuals and the importance of these 10 amendments to the
ratification of the US Constitution.

53FA40580DB94E1B9B1B42903A7D91C7.description: Explain the role of the courts and the judicial branch of government, and identify their power to evaluate laws.

A21AA48159E648DBB5C97B4257B9260F.description: Explain the role of the president and the executive branch of government, and the president’s power to carry out laws.

B2CA04C58B354E4A87FAFE8550CBE4EB.description: Explain the role of Congress, identifying the House of Representatives and the Senate, and their power to make laws.

78757829E8B64B8C86B02A395E8426E4.description:
Analyze the US Constitution, naming the three branches of government: legislative, executive and judicial, and discussing
the concept of checks and balances.

1B3FBDFC88BB428FA74385E587054A50.description:
Evaluate the Constitutional debates about the size and role of a federal government and the compromises that delegates
reached in framing the Constitution (e.g., the Three-Fifths Compromise and the Connecticut Compromise).

BE311D1152DF417B829C5CE9061A21BE.description: Analyze the reasons for the creation of the Constitution.

80848D7398F542A8BC1EB3A3E48ADA40.description: Evaluate the ideals of the Declaration of Independence and assess the opportunities and contradictions of the document.

11F13AE20282421F9D491EC534EB49B0.description:
Evaluate the legacy of the European Americans who became the founders of a new nation including the contradiction that
many of them were champions of independence and freedom, as well as active enslavers.

558E2159000843BD906F84A3A88A3A92.description:
Analyze the impact of key battles and historical figures of the American Revolution and the Independence movement
including George Washington, Benjamin Franklin, Thomas Jefferson, James Armistead Lafayette, the First Rhode Island Regiment
and the Minutemen.

D8F528C6B5214C6680C9682670362B92.description:
Analyze the different perspectives and reactions of people across the Colonies to British actions and revolution (e.g.,
“Patriots,” “Loyalists,” people from different racial, ethnic, and socioeconomic statuses, and different Indigenous Nations).

38B3BD15D0294D5383A0FE07BA73CC69.description:
Explain acts of resistance taken by some colonists and the British response to colonial actions (e.g., boycotts, the Boston
Massacre, the Boston Tea Party, Intolerable Acts, etc.).

8C00938823C841B6971A0AD29BDC68F4.description:
Explain the significant events that created tension and contributed to calls from European Americans to take action against
Britain (e.g., the Great Awakening, the Sugar Act, the Stamp Act, the Townshend Acts, the Tea Act, the Intolerable Acts, etc.).

9701BEA7872C46AE966A803598EFACCC.description:
In this driving concept, students analyze historical figures and events that led to the formation of the United States. Students will
evaluate the reasons for the American Revolution and explain the events that lead to the creation of the United State
Constitution. Students will evaluate both the opportunities and limitations of the new Constitution and the government it
created.

CBBA1DEA1E584523BF77FDA85882057E.description:
Driving Concept 5: The Creation of a New Nation – The American Revolution and
Founding of the United States Government (1700s–1790s)

496007EA3DDC4D41925B7CCD409FA4C0.description: Compare the daily lives of different groups of people within colonial society, including women.

F30889F799CE4932A68C7C3FB102FD03.description:
Evaluate laws and policies across the colonies –– including the right to vote and slave codes –– to evaluate the extent to
which different individual populations have had access to freedom and power.

2923D6AE05A0460FB0315754E29F7755.description:
Evaluate the cultural and technological contributions of people of African descent –– both enslaved and free –– across the
colonies to American history and society.

A48BB05B450146CB92B3694F6825A4D4.description:
Analyze the diverse histories of people who were kidnapped from Western Africa (e.g., enslaved people were not a
monolith, they represented a diverse group of people who spoke numerous languages, embodied various belief systems, etc.).

9104B4EC808E4B27AEACC6508D40FD4F.description:
Analyze the language used in primary and/or secondary sources to describe the “Triangular Slave Trade,” or the “Trade of
Enslaved People” to explain the history and historiography of slavery.

59AADF0F1A8B429F9ABF054BE327DBB7.description: Locate and compare key geographical, cultural, religious, and economic characteristics of the Thirteen Colonies

629B8CCE505D41AD9666CC69975931C2.description:
Analyze the experience and treatment of enslaved people in different parts of the Colonies, including experiences in
Northern and Southern colonies.

2B518C8D697449E399C95516EE891315.description: Evaluate the significance of 1619 when enslaved Africans were forcibly brought to the shores of Virginia by Europeans.

8A961E9A79C54C6395350CF0EE61C628.description:
Explain the reasons for establishing Plymouth and the Massachusetts Bay Colony, analyze the different experiences of early
life in the colony from the perspectives of Indigenous Nations and Europeans, and explain the significance of the Mayflower
Compact.

97BC3CBFEF614BEBA4267BD58E2DBFDA.description:
Explain the reasons for the establishment of Jamestown in 1607 and analyze the experiences of early life in the colony from
the perspectives of Indigenous Nations and Europeans.

99EA605E07274853B858A8284F56BFBC.description:
Analyze the impact of Spanish settlement on the Southern and Western United States, with a particular focus on Indigenous
Nations and the ways in which Indigenous Nations resisted Spanish settlement.

FC7A70A56CE941A4BC24D6DF4F5FCAEA.description: Explain the status, treatment, and experiences of European indentured servants.

292DE66658004E7088D0DE3638F91596.description:
Explain the reasons for enslavement and describe the experiences of individuals who were kidnapped and brought to the
Americas from Africa as enslaved people using primary sources.

A1022749666848A0A9E81CE4316F2E68.description:
Explain the reasons for the start of the slave trade in Africa and compare how different African societies resisted or
responded to the slave trade (e.g., the resistance of Queen Nzinga Mbande).

4FECC826D73D4CBD867626A20E69A36A.description:
Evaluate primary sources to make claims about the experiences, motivations, and legacies of different Europeans who
traveled across the Atlantic between 1607 and 1700.

FBC196BE21764CB8BAB1DF16C48743FD.description:
Compare and contrast maps of Indigenous Nations and land at the start of each century from 1500 to the present with a
special focus on areas east of the Mississippi River.

10489351A61A4CBCBA3E9F196B3D612C.description:
In this driving concept, students will analyze key events, geographical features and primary and secondary sources to better
analyze life in the early colonies. They will begin their investigation through a study of Jamestown and Plymouth, examining the
motives for colonization and settlement. Students will also analyze the institution of slavery and the diverse lived experiences
and methods of resistance of those who were enslaved by Europeans. Students will also evaluate the cultural, legal and
economic structures in the Thirteen Colonies to analyze the reasons for the American Revolution and the eventual founding of
the United States.

53439CA9A08B44DFB1B0DF84630673E3.description: Driving Concept 4: Life in the Colonies – Rebellions and the Roots of Revolution (1500s1700s)

4916A76397264EE3B95E7F8535661C70.description:
Evaluate the global impact of European colonization in regard to cultural and social shifts (e.g., exchange of foods, diseases,
enslaved humans, etc., often coined the “Columbian Exchange”).

02D1806F9A8C487B948136808BEFBFBC.description: Describe examples of Indigenous Nations’ resistance to European colonization, or subjugation, capture and enslavement.

76E88AD40740440CA134C15E5A446EFC.description:
Assess the immediate and enduring impact of the arrival of European nations in the Americas through the perspective of
Indigenous Nations, including the legacy of settler colonialism.

86EFF71A06E14C87A627F64032A7AA3E.description:
Evaluate the limitations of using European source material and terminology to understand the history of Indigenous Peoples
(e.g., use of the word “savage”; ideas that perpetuate a false hierarchy for human beings and the limitations of European
understanding of Indigenous cultures).

9FE3B0D561CE45798D0355960DB90AF7.description:
Compare the legacy of Christopher Columbus to primary source descriptions of his actions in the Americas, with specific
attention to the treatment and enslavement of Carib and Taino peoples.

3D9717B7FA5B4C9F9313AC10D47350DC.description:
Evaluate the purposes and ideologies of early European colonization using primary sources (e.g., Vikings, Christopher
Columbus, Hernán Cortés, etc.).

D45F063E60904EA5A33B77D623D12550.description:
In this driving concept, students will analyze the arrival of European colonists in the Americas and the consequences of
colonization from perspectives of European and Indigenous Nations. Students will analyze concepts of land ownership and basic
human rights, and the impact of European colonization and oppression on the human rights of Indigenous Nations.

5AF04CA8432848E2BD7EDD59CAFB473C.description: Driving Concept 3: Europeans Enter the Americas (1400s-1500s)

77E076E3B2714A248AC663E867392E69.description:
Explain the diverse legacy of Indigenous Nations on the political geography of America today, including areas where
Indigenous Nations retain sovereignty.

2DFF542DE36F4B7584AC7C7D2B0DD342.description:
Evaluate the governing model created by the Haudenosaunee Confederacy and the ways women and men exercised
political power.

BB8A03727D2E467D901353770664172C.description: Analyze reasons for and consequences of the formation of the Haudenosaunee Confederacy.

2EF9DB718DC7420E92CF16598DB5B2BB.description:
Compare Indigenous practices of land cultivation across the Americas in the 12th and 13th centuries, including
environmentally sustainable practices (e.g., the use of controlled fires, the building and development of roads, etc.).

7A23C5DF375F4D308F6EBD03F7F665A7.description:
Compare the political structures, technological achievements, religious beliefs, and social structures of the Aztec and Inca
empires.

14BF751E14A147B8A1DE3FA0C8E5BE9C.description:
Analyze the political structure, technological achievements, and legacy of the Mississippian, Hohokam, or Haudenosaunee
societies.

874838C4B4754E3BB75F7F2C31F47E05.description:
Analyze the changes to the political geography of the Americas in the 12th, 13th and 14th centuries and identify the
geographic locations of major civilizations in the Americas during this time.

FE2CC918D185429C930316B8D194DC03.description:
In this driving concept, students will compare and analyze archaeological artifacts, as well as primary and secondary sources to
explain how geography impacted the daily lives of peoples and communities in the past. Students will evaluate the ways cultural
and technological innovations were both similar and unique across time and place.

4B49B66A05584E88B23BB9A3EB5953E7.description: Driving Concept 2: Civilizations of the Americas (1100 CE to 1500 CE)

9FB66A251BEA4A4D9DF0DA96FD495D4C.description:
Analyze the development of physical documentation, such as the writing and iconographic systems of Indigenous peoples
across the Americas to make claims about historic societies (e.g., Cave of the Painted Rock in current-day Brazil; the writing
system developed by the Maya; glyphs of the Grand Canyon; etc.).

A6960E332E9D4BAB8DF7A5BA04A016C8.description:
Explain the development of various economic and systems of trade of Indigenous peoples across the Americas using
historical evidence (e.g., Inca ceque system; the use of cacao as currency and the trade of turquoise and minerals in Chaco).

2E1B02E4AFDE4D2F96A4F22CE7435D67.description:
Compare the development of agricultural practices of Indigenous peoples across the Americas, including the Hohokam
cultivation of corn, beans, squash, and cotton.

9EE32AF615E84F42A622CB21EF4264C6.description:
Compare different theories about how and when people began to migrate around the globe and populate the Americas (e.g.,
land-bridge theory; Beringea; Yana Rhinoceros Horn Site and evidence of mammoth hunting; coastal-route theory; Clovis sites).

9D950781C8AB4D08B3255A4171682051.description:
Explain which natural resources were available in North America before 1100 CE and use a map to explain how the
availability of natural resources has changed over time.

CF142CBAD0AA471A93C42FE940D23466.description:
Analyze how physical geography (e.g., natural resources available, waterways, landforms) impacts the choices people make
and how people impact the natural environment.

409870DE0F494C2EA43FE98DEC359DEF.description:
Evaluate the strengths and weaknesses of evidence (e.g., archeological evidence, artifacts, oral history, secondary sources) to
understand events and life in the past.

6F4295F9860E498298A2289DA9581893.description:
In this driving concept, students will compare and analyze archaeological artifacts as well as primary and secondary sources to
explain how geography impacted the daily lives of peoples and communities in the past. Students will evaluate the ways cultural
and technological innovations were both similar and unique across time and place.

62057C1E7BCF40648DE1E218C240C75C.description: Driving Concept 1: Early Societies in the Americas (13000 BCE to 1100 CE)
